docs.lead_paragraph: When Christopher Reed left here nine years ago to study engineering at Penn State, he assumed he was gone for good. A steelworker's son, he had had firsthand experience with the havoc that the steady decline of Big Steel had wreaked on the area's job market. ''I figured I'd be in California by now,'' Mr. Reed said. Mr. Reed came back when he graduated in 1994, but only to use his parent's home as a base for job hunting. Five months later, though, he was working at QED, a Bethlehem company that makes gallium arsenide wafers for the semiconductor industry.

headline.main: Lehigh Phoenix Rises From Big Steel's Ashes; Eastern Pennsylvania Region Recovers By Turning to Technology Companies

docs.abstract: Lehigh Valley, Pa, once thought to be irretrievably damaged by collapse of steelmaking in area, is on rebound due in part to influx of new high-technology operations and expansion of business services; region's unemployment rate, which four years ago was 7.7 percent, is now only 3.7 percent, some 65 high-technology companies have moved into valley or been founded there in last five years, representing 38,500 jobs--or about 12 percent of area's total employment; it is striking example of extent to which high technology is transforming some of most damaged areas of Rust Belt's industrial economy; survey by state-financed economic agency indicates that technology companies accounted for 3,500 new jobs in valley last year, and are expected to create another 4,000 over next two years; graph; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Thatcher Contradicts Party On Touchy Issue of Europe Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took center stage at the annual Conservative Party conference and made clear she was still smarting from her banishment from office nine years ago. In a speech, she trod underfoot her party's attempts to keep Britain relatively in league with the European Union. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives today passed a bill creating tax breaks to help millions of people buy health insurance. But it also took a procedural step that may jeopardize legislation to define patients' rights and regulate health maintenance organizations. President Clinton and House Democrats cried foul. The White House said Mr. Clinton would veto the bill authorizing new tax breaks for the purchase of health insurance if the measure reached his desk in the form approved by the House tonight. The bill's benefits would go mainly to a small number of healthy, affluent people, the Administration said.

headline.main: HEALTH CARE BILL PASSED BY HOUSE INTENSIFIES FUROR

docs.abstract: House passes, 227 to 205, bill creating tax breaks to help millions of people buy health insurance; White House says Pres Clinton will veto bill because its benefits would go mainly to small number of healthy, affluent people; says bill would cost more than $40 billion over 10 years and help fewer than 1 percent of people who lack coverage; Republican majority, in unusual procedural move, votes to attach tax bill to whatever patient protection bill is approved by House; Democrats say they have enough votes to pass bipartisan HMO patients' rights bill drafted by Reps Charles Norwood and John D Dingell; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The House of Representatives today passed a bill creating tax breaks to help millions of people buy health insurance. But it also took a procedural step that may jeopardize legislation to define patients' rights and regulate health maintenance...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans approved a tax package yesterday that expands tax-free medical savings accounts, a change that could lure healthy and wealthy people out of insurance pools. That is bad enough, but the Republican leadership, knowing that Democrats oppose such accounts, have decided to attach that legislation as a poison pill to any patients' rights bill that comes out of the House. That ploy is an attempt to block a sound bipartisan patients' rights bill that will be debated today. Even so, the bill, drafted by Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, and John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, appears to have sufficient support from Democrats, as well as more than 20 insurgent Republicans, to pass. These lawmakers know voters want to be able to hold health maintenance organizations accountable for bad decisions. The Norwood-Dingell bill, alone among the alternatives scheduled for debate today, meets that need. It would give patients the right to see specialists and get independent review of plan decisions and easier access to care. It would also give consumers the right to sue health plans in state courts for injuries and deaths caused by improper denials of care.
docs.abstract: Editorial backs patients' rights bill sponsored by Republican Repr Charles Norwood and Democrat John Dingell, but criticizes efforts of Republicans to block it by attaching 'poison pill' tax package that expands tax-free medical savings accounts that is opposed by Democrats; says, despite ploy, bill meets needs of Americans who want to hold health maintenance organizations responsible for bad decisions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I've got a lot of professional memory,'' Representative Charlie Norwood said this afternoon, reflecting on his experience with managed care companies in the years he practiced dentistry in Augusta, Ga. ''I know how they deny care,'' he went on, leaning against a wall near the House floor, sweating through his shirt after hours of debating and arm-twisting on behalf of his bill that would establish more stringent standards for insurers and health maintenance organizations.

headline.main: A Rebellious Team Player -- Charles Whitlow Norwood Jr.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Robert H. Frank (''Not Insured, and Not Worried,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 6) argues for a direct Federal subsidy for individual health insurance, an idea that will solve nothing. Even a cursory examination of the history of government subsidies demonstrates that they are never more than short-term solutions, with costs eventually rising to absorb the subsidy.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Robert H. Frank (Op-Ed, Oct. 6) recommends that the Government expand health insurance coverage by reimbursing every American family for health insurance premiums. He estimates that such a reform would be less costly than the current system. A better idea would be to expand the Medicare program to cover all the medically necessary health care costs for all Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Connecticut's largest network of doctors filed a lawsuit yesterday against Physicians Health Services, the state's largest managed care provider, claiming it is not paying doctors on time or giving them a big enough role in patient care decisions. The lawsuit, filed in Superior Court in New Haven, seeks a court order requiring P.H.S. to comply with the terms of its contract with the Connecticut State Medical Society-Independent Practice Association, a network of 6,500 physicians that is owned by the medical society. The suit also seeks an undisclosed amount for damages. P.H.S., based in Shelton, has about 500,000 members in Connecticut.

headline.main: Metro Business; Doctors' Group Sues Connecticut H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week we learned that poverty in the United States has been declining of late, but now we're told that the number of Americans without health insurance has risen to 44.3 million -- 833,000 more than a year ago and 4.5 million more than when Bill Clinton took office in 1993. Even in households with annual incomes of at least $50,000, the number of people without insurance increased last year, to 12.2 million. In the midst of the longest sustained economic boom in history, with the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years, how is it possible that the ranks of the uninsured keep swelling?
docs.abstract: Prof Robert H Frank Op-Ed article urges Government reverse rise in number of people without health insurance by reimbursing families that buy insurance up to $3,000 a year (M)
